I shall name it <u>tractus externus <\u>. <s>From <\s> [The 
<u>tractus internus <\u> is made up of bundles cut cross-wise &
obliquely. They are firm dense <s>bundles <\s> bands wh: have a 
peculiar glistening appearance in a clarified prepar-
ation. Below it receives a fasciculus <s>bundle <\s> of considerable 
size from the gyrus rectus, and above many fibres
enter it from the first & second frontal convolutions.
By far the greater supply of fibres is evidently derived 
from the latter source. This <u>tractus internus <\u> becomes 
further back the <u>corpus callosum <\u>. The <u>tractus medius <\u>
as will be seen from <s>the di Figures figure 2<\s> Fig 2.
commences a little above the <u>tractus internus <\u>: it runs 
down for a considerable distance, and ends in a 
free extremity. It tapers off insensibly at each end.
Further description will be necessary to explain what it is.
The <u>tractus internus <\u> is made up of an upper or perpendicular 
<s>pe <\s> and of a lower or <s>curved <\s> almost horizontal <s>oblique <\s> (e.e.e) Its fibres <s>are <\s> pass <s>a<\s> somewhat 
obliquely backwards, & consequently in a perpendicular section are cut not exactly 
transversely <s>across <\>, but very nearly so. The <s>obl curved <\s> horizontal part below 
<s>derives its fibres <\s> appears to arise from the gyrus rectus (Fig 2) more externally 
than the fasciculus above described <s>those of the tra <\s> going to the tractus internus; & from 
this they curve upwards for some distance, and then
are cut across evidently <s>from <\s> in turning backwards. The <u>tractus
